description: Humans relate to one another in families, groups, organizations and communities.  Through
social systems theory, ethics and a strengths perspective, students apply prerequisite and advanced
theoretical research material from biology, sociology, and psychology to assess situations
encountered by social workers. Diverse examples are drawn from literature -- Love in the
Driest Season, The Color of Water, A Poison Stronger than Love -- and from
students' autobiographies. Prerequisites: Sociology 121, Psychology 241, and Biology 123 or 243;
open to non-majors by permission of program director only. Offered Fall Semester.
fullname: Human Behavior in the Social Environment
